commander.name: Lieutenant-General Kenneth Arthur Noel Anderson
commander.previous_service: Commanded II Corps (UK), Eastern Command. Selected to command First Army for Operation Torch by General Eisenhower.

command.headquarters_location: Algiers, Algeria (from November 8, 1942) - advancing into Tunisia

Ordnance QF 6-pounder (57mm).note: Modern anti-tank gun, both divisions equipped

anti_aircraft.note: AA defense provided by attached RAF units and US anti-aircraft battalions

supply_logistics.supply_status: STRAINED - First Army faces severe logistical challenges during Operation Torch and Tunisia Campaign. Primary constraints: (1) Insufficient port capacity at Algiers and Bone - competing with US II Corps and French forces. (2) Extended supply lines from Algiers to Tunisia front (300-400km). (3) Heavy rains November-December turn roads to mud, hampering truck transport. (4) Rapid advance from landing sites to Tunisia outpaces logistics tail. (5) Blade Force advancing ahead of main supply echelons. Supply sufficient for defensive operations, inadequate for sustained offensive without consolidation.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Tunisian/Algerian terrain - VERY different from Western Desert. Hills, valleys, farmland, mountains. Heavy rains November-December turn roads and tracks to mud, severely limiting tank mobility. Coastal plains near landing beaches, mountainous terrain along Tunisia-Algeria border.

subordinate_units.note: V Corps operational from November 1942 but no 1942-Q4 file exists. Contains 6th Armoured and 78th Infantry Divisions. First Army's primary British corps.
Blade Force spearhead formed from 17th/21st Lancers. 'Run for Tunis' November 1942.
Assault division for Algiers landings. Guards brigade (1st Guards Brigade).
Under operational command of First Army for Tunisia Campaign. American formation not included in British First Army aggregates.
French Arm√©e d'Afrique forces under operational command of First Army after Vichy collapse. Not included in British First Army aggregates.

tactical_doctrine.role: Expeditionary field army formed for Operation Torch - amphibious invasion of French North Africa (Algiers sector) and rapid advance into Tunisia to seize Tunis and Bizerta before Axis reinforcement. Mission: Coordinate Allied forces (British, American, French) in Tunisia Campaign.
special_capabilities: Coalition warfare coordination (British, US, French forces)
tactical_innovations: Blade Force concept - regimental battlegroup with combined arms
Coalition command structure integrating British, American, French forces
Amphibious-to-exploitation rapid transition (landing to armoured advance)
Adaptation from desert warfare training to Tunisian hill/mud terrain
known_issues: NO COMBAT EXPERIENCE - First Army formed August 1942, first action November 1942
Extended supply lines (300-400km from Algiers to Tunisia front)
Insufficient port capacity at Algiers/Bone - logistics bottleneck
Heavy rains limit tank mobility (mud severely degrades armoured operations)
Terrain mismatch - trained for desert, fighting in Tunisian hills
Axis reinforcement via Tunisia/Sicily faster than Allied buildup
Rushed deployment - advance outpaced logistics and consolidation
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: NOT APPLICABLE - First Army operations in Tunisia/Algeria, NOT Western Desert. Terrain is Mediterranean/European style (hills, farmland, mud) not sand desert. Units trained for desert warfare but operating in completely different environment.

scenario_suitability: Operation Torch (8 November 1942) - Algiers sector landings
special_rules: Fresh formations (full strength, high morale, modern equipment)
Coalition command (coordination penalties with US/French allies)
Mud movement penalty (Tunisian rains reduce tank mobility 50%)

source: WebSearch: British First Army Operation Torch Tunisia 1942
WebSearch: Kenneth Anderson First Army commander
British Military History - Tunisia 1942-1943 Overview and Higher Formations
validation.validated_by: Claude Code Agent - Manual Extraction (orchestrated workflow)
required_field_gaps: V Corps 1942-Q4 file missing (bottom-up aggregation gap)
Army headquarters staff exact strength estimated

chief_of_staff.reason: Chief of Staff name for First Army in Q4 1942 not found in available sources
chief_of_staff.mitigation: UK National Archives - First Army war diaries, staff appointment records

v_corps_1942q4.reason: V Corps 1942-Q4 file does not exist despite being marked complete in WORK_QUEUE. Bottom-up aggregation gap. Aggregated directly from divisions instead.
v_corps_1942q4.mitigation: Extract V Corps 1942-Q4 separately, then re-aggregate First Army

army_hq_staff.reason: Army headquarters staff strength not documented in sources - estimated from standard British field army establishment 1942
army_hq_staff.estimate_method: British field army HQ typically ~1,650 personnel (280 officers, 425 NCOs, 945 enlisted)
army_hq_staff.mitigation: War Office establishment tables for field army headquarters 1942

notes: Q4 1942: First Army in TUNISIA/ALGERIA (Operation Torch theater), NOT Western Desert
Formed: August 8, 1942 in UK for Operation Torch planning
Only 2 British divisions in Q4 1942: 6th Armoured, 78th Infantry (CONFIRMED)
46th Infantry Division NOT in theater Q4 1942 (arrived January 3, 1943)
V Corps operational from November 1942 but file missing - aggregated from divisions
Also coordinated US II Corps and French XIX Corps (not included in aggregates)
Tier 2 classification due to missing V Corps file, unknown Chief of Staff, estimated HQ staff
CRITICAL: V Corps 1942-Q4 missing despite WORK_QUEUE showing complete - data inconsistency

discovered_units.source: WebSearch results and British Military History - Tunisia 1942-1943
discovered_units.reason: V Corps (Lt-Gen Charles Allfrey) was operational subordinate formation of First Army from November 1942, but 1942-Q4 file missing despite WORK_QUEUE showing complete
discovered_units.combat_evidence: V Corps commanded 6th Armoured Division and 78th Infantry Division during Operation Torch landings (8 November 1942) and subsequent Tunisia Campaign operations including 'Run for Tunis' (November-December 1942). Primary British corps of First Army.

aggregation_notes: Aggregated from 2 subordinate units. Previous totals: 31800 personnel, 165 tanks.
